Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
A field homomorphism \\(\sigma: L \longrightarrow L'\\) between two field extensions \\(L / K\\) and \\(L' / K\\) is called a \\(K\\)-homomorphism if it restricts to the identity map on \\(K\\).
Does the concept of a/an Galois group of a Field Extension need to be defined for a definition of a/an K-homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a K-homomorphism involves a field homomorphism between two field extensions that restricts to the identity on the base field K. This definition is self-contained and does not inherently require the concept of a Galois group. A K-homomorphism is defined purely in terms of its action on elements of the fields involved and its restriction to the identity on K.

On the other hand, the Galois group of a field extension L/K is the group of all field automorphisms of L that fix every element of K. While this concept is related to K-homomorphisms in that it also deals with automorphisms that fix K, the definition of a K-homomorphism does not depend on the concept of the Galois group. The Galois group is a specific type of group formed under certain conditions (typically when the extension is normal and separable), and it involves the study of all such automorphisms collectively as a group.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of a K-homomorphism do not require the concept of the Galois group. The existence and properties of K-homomorphisms can be fully understood without reference to the Galois group.
